title: What kind of music will you be listening to in 2020? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for your request! In 2020, I look to continue the trend (in fact, I already have) of discovering new bands within the seemingly endless sub-genres of heavy metal. There are SO many bands across these sub-genres that it would be next to impossible to get bored doing so, and even if one particular style got stale, there are a ton more to choose from. What I’ve seen over the past few years that I’m really excited about, is a trend of “epic” metal, composed and executed by bands that have taken on an almost medieval aesthetic in their songwriting. Bands like Wilderun, Atlantean Kodex, and Obsequiae, whose music reminds me of traveling some vast, green countryside in pursuit of rescuing a fair maiden in distress. If it sounds corny, it is a bit, but it also captures the imagination and leads to some really great sounding metal. I also will be expanding my catalog of more extreme forms of metal. Death metal bands like Blood Incantation and Gatecreeper have crafted some real compelling cacophonies over the past year or two, and I look forward to adding their CD’s to my collection. Similarly, a few Black metal groups such as Dark Fortress are high up on my list to really explore further this year. Other than that, I’m looking forward to new releases by some of the more established, “mainstream” metal acts scheduled for 2020: Lamb of God, Mastodon, and Gojira all supposedly have new music this year, and I’m eagerly and patiently awaiting their arrivals as well. I realize this is a very “metal-centric” list, but as mentioned above, with so many varying styles and sounds, it’s really easy to get lost in everything that falls under the metal banner. I’m always open to new sounds, new genres, and new influences, so if you have any recommendations for something, I’m all ears! -Mike

The easy (and somewhat facetious) answer is that as a music writer, I’ll be listening to whatever artists and PR people send to me. I received more than 250 albums in 2019, very few of which were my choices - I do occasionally reach out to an artist, but mostly things arrive unsolicited. This kind of listening occupies a majority of my music time. Lately I’ve been seeking out modern “classical” composers, especially chamber music involving acoustic instruments combined with electronics. I’m also loving a new crop of jazz from around the world that mixes in electronics and classical music. The third stream I’m really fascinated with is groups like Dongyang Gozupa, combining Korean music with modern sounds. Surface, by DONGYANG GOZUPA
